text:
SHINTA WIDJAJA
KAMDANI: Well, it's

been quite a tough
journey for me.

My parents actually have two
girls, two female children.
So they don't have boys.

So I think the expectation for
me is that I might be a girl,

but like any other boys, one
day you take over the business.

MEG RITHMIRE: And you knew
that from a young age,
from very early?
SHINTA WIDJAJA KAMDANI: Yes.

And I think that expectation
is also the treatment.

So my father has always treated
me like I'm one of the boys.

I don't have a boy, so you
are the boy that I don't have.

So this is something
that I have to fight for.

And I think, even living
in Indonesia, we--

of course, there's
a certain culture.

Female leaders are not fully
acceptable in that sense

that-- of course,
it's much better now,
the gender equality.

But still, women in
the leadership role

is not something that
is quite common here.

So this is something
that I have to deal with.

I always call myself
a triple minority.
First, I'm a woman.

Second, I'm a non-Muslim, and
third, I'm of Chinese descent.

So this triple minority
goes [? with ?] me

in my journey of my
career and my life here.

And I think this is something
that I have to continue
breaking the ceiling.

But from there, I
become stronger.

And I think I learned a
lot from that process,
and I prove myself.

At the end of the day, I'm not
just the daughter of an owner.

But I'm able to make it and
deliver because of who I am.

And whether that's a man
or a woman, we can do it.
